May the Lord and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ add to you strength and understanding.
Dear Brother, I have received two letters from you a few days ago. Since I have not replied and your fellow countryman has promised to deliver my letters, I now answer.
First, you recommended two and if you recommend more, they will be highly recommended by you to me. After the synod all the ministers of the province were delegated so that there is no place left, but it will not be harmful to have such acquaintances among the brothers, so that in the future they can be subordinated more safely when they are needed in the ministry.
Then you will see soon what kind of action Capito has taken with us when they come out from the Frobenius press. I was all in this, that the cause of Megander, which had been very contentious between the ministers and the senate, the deacons and the people, could be happily decided without the judgment of prophetic freedom and that the ministers recognize that the matter was most advanced by not harsh scolding but by gentle and salty modesty. He divided the acts into heads and spent more labor for the weakness of man than anyone would have dared to demand. Then Simon Sulcerus, a young man of great hope, a student of our city in studies, a disciple of Grinius, will give it the same Latin, so that our senate may have the beginnings of his studies. Whatever pleases or displeases you, you will freely comment with us. Above all, I wish that everything be done openly and from the heart, as if in the presence of one God and Lord Jesus Christ, whom we must also look upon as one in all.

Your own Berch. H.

May the Lord and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ add to you strength and intelligence.
My dearest brother, I have recently received two letters from you. Since I did not reply and your co-countryman promised to deliver my response, here it is.
First of all, you recommended two people and if you recommend more, they will be highly recommended by you. After the Synod of the province, all the ministers were assigned, so there is no place left now; still it will be useful to know our fellow brothers, so they can be subordinated more safely in the ministry in the future.
Then, you will soon see what and how Capito has dealt with us when the books from Frobenius will be published. I was totally focused on making Megandri's case, which had been extremely contentious between the ministers and the Senate, diaconesses and the people, could be solved without the judgment of prophetic freedom and the ministers would recognize that the best way to promote the thing was not harsh criticism but a gentle and wise modesty. He divided the acts into sections and spent more effort than anyone would have dared to demand due to the weakness of the man. The same Latin will be given by Simon Sulcerus, a very promising young man, a student of our city in studies, a student of Grinęi, so that our Senate will have the first fruits of their studies. Whatever you find pleasing or displeasing, you can freely comment with us. I sincerely wish that everything would be done as if in the presence of one God and Lord Jesus Christ, whom we must consider as one in all.

Although I do not yet have an explanation for the purpose of study and Pharaoh's obstinacy, nevertheless I would like that, if you can afford so much leisure, you should have it. What you promise me, the explanation of prophetic office and of Hebrew, I would like you to deliver with great success; for you can hardly believe how well your and Pellican's spirit pleases me. Perhaps it does not please the Lord that those, who agree best with each other, should be together, so that we may learn to break our affections and be subjected and yield to one another. I wonder what keeps our Pellican, that his works so long expected do not come out yet; exhort the man, that he may not bury the talent committed to him, and let him think, that though he should render to the world what he has, yet greater things may remain for others. Let him serve and dispense his goods to his brethren, and not think of digging out a treasure of sacred writings. And you also should not keep us any longer in suspense. I have spoken with Froschower at Bern, that whatever shall come out of your or Pellican's press, he should send from the beginning.
Megander is in good health concerning the pulpit and also with us. All things are more quiet. As for what you are solicitous for the harmony of both cities, I also am solicitous, knowing that either of them without the other is easily perishing. Some one amongst you has written to the Lord from Innsbruck that it can be done best by the Baselers. But other beginnings will be necessary. O that your Röstius, a man very acceptable to us, had even the least business with us, and of his own accord spoke with a few of us and more understanding; easy beginnings of peace would be. Think and order what you will.
Lastly, I would like you to indicate as soon as possible where I could send my letters to Capito with security. For I was about to write to him serious things. You will salute Leon, Pellican, your father, and Zuinglius' widow. Be not anxious for your son; he is wholly ours, and a boy of good disposition; Trempius will perform the fatherly offices, and we will do it too, when our help is needed.

seg.output:
Finally, I would like you to indicate quickly how our letter could be safely returned to Capito. For I was about to write him a serious matter. Andreas has been called to be a deacon in Vilmäringen. You can write to him. Greet Leon, Pellicanus, your father, and Zuinglii's widow. Do not worry for the little one; he is entirely ours, and a good-natured boy; Trempius will fulfill his fatherly duties, and we will do the same, if our help is needed. I hear that your brother has been given a province.
Farewell, that we may write more often. The times, and the changes of times, and the crowds and dangers of men, require it.
Bernae, 9 February, 32.
Your, as if he was, Berch. H.
To Huldricho [!] Bullinger, a herald of the word of God at Zurich, an eminently learned and pious man, and the brother most dear to me forever.
